name: Chatling Ai by Codex Solutions International
title: Chatling Ai by Codex Solutions International
description: How to integrate Chatling Ai with Make.com

children.text: Chatling is a no-code AI chatbot platform for building and deploying customizable chatbots on websites and WhatsApp, offering multilingual support and analytics. Integrating with Make.com enables automated workflows, enhanced lead capture, and seamless data exchange between Chatling and other apps.
This is AI-generated content based on official Chatling Ai documentation. The content may still contain errorsâ€”please verify important information. If you have questions, contact
How to get support on Chatling Ai

Chatling Ai is a community-developed application and is subjected to the developer's terms and conditions, which may include applicable fees. Make does not maintain or support this integration. For assistance, please https://f.make.com/r/reachout?app_name=Chatling%20Ai&app_slug=chatling-ai-community&app_unique_id=chatling-x8y3ls.
To use the Chatling Ai app in Make,
you must have an active Chatling account and an API Key,
create your account on Chatling Ai.
To install this app, you need Admin, Owner, or App Developer permissions.
the on-screen instructions to complete the setup.
To get started, you must first create a connection between Chatling Ai and
, allowing the two services to communicate.
You can connect using the following method: API Keys.
You need to generate your API key.
Go to your Chatling account and open the Project Settings.
Press the New API key button.
Enter a name for the key and press Generate key.
Copy the newly created key. The API key will be displayed once only, so note it down and store it in a secure place.
Some community developers require an additional specific
from the community developer's dashboard, generally found under
, add the Chatling Ai module to your
If you add a module with an instant tag, click
field, enter a name for the connection.
you copied from your Chatling Ai or follow the on-screen instructions to create the connection. You must also enter any required third-party API keys obtained earlier.
For detailed information on connecting an application, see
After connecting to the Chatling Ai app, you can choose from a list of available modules to build your
This module lets you add new link data sources directly to your knowledge base, making it easy to expand and organize your collection of valuable resources.
Add new text data sources to your knowledge base, enabling you to expand and enrich the information your system can access and utilize.

Chat with the AI using information from your knowledge base to get helpful, accurate responses to your questions. This module allows you to interact with the AI, which uses your stored data to provide tailored answers and support.
Allows you to create a brand new chatbot, either by starting from scratch or by using a pre-designed template to help you get started quickly.
Creates an exact copy of a specific chatbot using its unique ID, allowing you to easily replicate an existing chatbot and its settings.
Fetches detailed information about a specific chatbot using its unique ID.
Retrieve a comprehensive list of all AI languages currently supported by the service, helping you see which languages you can use for your AI-powered tasks.
Retrieve a comprehensive list of all AI models that are currently supported by the service.
Retrieve a comprehensive list of all chatbot templates that are currently available for you to use or customize.
Retrieves a complete list of all chatbots that are part of your project, making it easy to view and manage each one.
Retrieve a detailed list of all the data sources that have been added to your knowledge base, helping you keep track of the information connected to your system.
Retrieve a complete list of every member who is part of the specified project.
Perform a custom API request to the connected service, allowing you to interact with specific endpoints and access or send data that may not be available through the standard modules.
You can look for more templates in
, where you'll find thousands of pre-created

customCSS:
<style>
@media print {
  html, body {
    overflow-x: visible;
  }
}
#tally-widget-button {
  position: fixed !important;
  background-color: #FFFFFF;
  display: none;
  visibility: visible !important;
  opacity: 1 !important;
  color: #0C121D;
  border: 2px solid #0C121D;
  border-radius: 4px;
  align-items: center;
  justify-content: center;
  font-size: 14px;
  font-weight: 600;
  font-family: 'Inter';
  text-align: center;
  box-shadow: 0 4px 6px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.2);
  cursor: pointer;
  z-index: 999999 !important;
  -webkit-tap-highlight-color: transparent;
  outline: none;
  touch-action: manipulation;
  pointer-events: auto;
  transform: translate3d(0, 0, 0);
}
.button-text {
  display: inline-block;
  margin-right: 8px;
}
.button-text::before {
  content: attr(data-text);
}
#tally-widget-popup {
  position: fixed;
  background-color: white;
  display: none;
  border-radius: 12px;
  box-shadow: 0 10px 20px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.4);
  z-index: 999999;
  overflow: hidden;
  border: 0px solid #0C121D;
  padding-top: 30px;
}
#tally-widget-close {
  position: absolute;
  top: 10px;
  right: 10px;
  background: none;
  border: none;
  font-size: 36px;
  font-weight: bold;
  padding: 8px;
  cursor: pointer;
  color: #0C121D;
}

  .ab-plugin-wrapper .ab-link-block-item .ab-link {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
    font-family: 'Inter' !important;
  }

  .dark .ab-plugin-wrapper .ab-link-block-item .ab-link {
    color: #F6F6F6 !important;
  }
  
  #main-column > div > div > div.flex.flex-1.w-full.justify-center.pb-0 > div > div.flex.items-center.pl-0.pr-2.mb-5.xl\:-mt-1\.5 > div > div > div > div:nth-child(1) > div.flex.pr-2.text-gray-500.items-center {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  a.ab-tree-navigation-link-active span {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  .ab-public-space-links-wrap .ab-public-space-link:first-of-type {
    border-color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  .ab-toc-item-active a{
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  #main-column .text-ab-blue-500 span {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  
  #main-column .text-ab-blue-500 {
    text-decoration-color: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  .ab-nav-left:hover > svg,
  .ab-nav-left:hover .text-gray-300,
  .ab-nav-left:hover .ab-nav-left-text {
     color: #7302D5 !important;
     stroke: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  .ab-nav-right:hover > svg,
  .ab-nav-right:hover .text-gray-300,
  .ab-nav-right:hover .ab-nav-right-text {
     color: #7302D5 !important;
     stroke: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  
#tally-inline-popup {
  position: fixed;
  display: none;
  z-index: 999999;
  width: min(420px, 90vw);
  height: min(550px, 80vh);
  background: #fff;
  color: #0c121d;
  border: 1px solid rgba(0,0,0,0.08);
  border-radius: 12px;
  box-shadow: 0 12px 28px rgba(0,0,0,0.22), 0 2px 6px rgba(0,0,0,0.12);
  overflow: hidden;
  padding: 5px;
}

#tally-inline-popup iframe {
  width: 100%;
  height: 100%;
  border: 0;
  display: block;
  border-radius: 8px;
}

#tally-inline-popup .tip-close {
  position: absolute;
  top: 6px;
  right: 8px;
  width: 32px;
  height: 32px;
  line-height: 28px;
  font-size: 22px;
  text-align: center;
  background: rgba(255,255,255,0.85);
  border: 1px solid rgba(0,0,0,0.06);
  border-radius: 8px;
  cursor: pointer;
}

#main-column a[data-form-url],
#main-column a[data-tally-url] {
  color: #7302D5 !important;
  text-decoration: underline;
  text-underline-offset: 2px;
  text-decoration-thickness: 1.5px;
  font-weight: 600;
}

@media (max-width: 640px) {
  #tally-inline-popup {
    width: min(360px, 94vw);
    height: min(500px, 80vh);
  }
}

#main-column .ab-cta-button a.ab-cta-button {
  background-color: #7302D5;
}

/* Titles in purple */
.ab-link-blocks-wrapper .ab-link-block-item.ab-docs-card-mode .ab-link-block-content-wrap .font-bold {
  color: #7302D5 !important;
}

.ab-tree-navigation-link-active span {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
}

</style>

reusableContentVariables.name: string
reusableContentVariables.description: a list or sequence of characters (like letters, numbers, and symbols) used to represent text in a computer programming.

reusableContentVariables.name: Operations
reusableContentVariables.description: An operation is a single module run to process data or check for new data.

reusableContentVariables.name: Credits
reusableContentVariables.description: Credits (formerly operations) are the currency for running scenarios.

reusableContentVariables.name: Route
reusableContentVariables.description: A route is a path that data can flow through in a scenario, visualized as the dotted lines between modules.
